title: Headteacher BANS parents taking mobile phones onto playground - to stop them ignoring their children
text:
A primary school headteacher has banned mobile phones on her school's playground - after she noticed parents were too engrossed in their calls to talk to their children about their day.

Wendy Cathie, a mother-of-three, and headteacher at St Peter's CE Primary School, Leigh, in Manchester, announced the new rules on social media over the weekend.

All mobile phone use has been banned from the playground in an effort to encourage parents to actually listen when their child tries to tell them about their day, instead of paying more attention to electronic devices.

Wendy Cathie, a mother-of-three, and headteacher at St Peter's CE Primary School (pictured), Leigh, in Manchester, has banned mobile phones from the playground to encourage parents to pay more attention to their children as they leave school

Wendy Cathie (pictured) banned parents from using phones on the playground

The head of the 410-pupil school for the last seven years told the Manchester Evening News: 'It's always lovely walking around school at the end of the day, seeing the buzz of the children getting ready.'

'It really pulls at your heartstrings when you see parents on phone calls and pupils are running out to see them', Ms Cathie added.

Some parents are so engrossed in their phones they don't even greet their children with a 'hello', instead choosing to 'just walk off', expecting their child to follow, she says.

In a post on the school's Facebook page on Sunday evening Ms Cathie reminded parents how important conversation is for a child's brain development.

It read: 'How many of you are so engrossed in a conversation with your friend or on the phone, that you forget to say to your child "Hi how was your day?" smile warmly at them or give them a hug? I am sure we have all done that.

In a post on the school's Facebook page (pictured) on Sunday evening Ms Cathie reminded parents how important conversation is for a child's brain development

'The smiles on their faces when they notice you on the playground. Often running to you and starting a conversation before you can hear them over the buzz of other people's conversations.'

She adds: 'Please take a moment to listen and talk to your child. The power of talk has a huge impact on our children's language development - it stimulates brain development.

'Their wisdom grows, their vocabulary becomes richer, and they develop curiosity, critical thinking and intelligence.

'In addition it supports a child to develop a good mental health.'

The primary school, which is taking part in Thursday's Hello Yellow day to raise money for YoungMinds, offers yoga as a PE option and 'does a lot of mindfulness', Ms Cathie says.

Some parents are so engrossed in their phones they don't even greet their children with a 'hello', instead choosing to 'just walk off', expecting their child to follow, Ms Cathie says (file)

'There was one parent on her phone yesterday so I just said "excuse me, we're now a mobile-free school" and she just said "oh right, sorry",' she added.

As for how they might deal with any conflict, she said: 'Ultimately the school belongs to us, it's our rules, so we'll just ask them nicely and hope the message gets across.

'Ultimately it's about the children and while they're in our care and our boundaries, that's what we're going to be asking for.'
description: Wendy Cathie, a mother-of-three, and headteacher at St Peter's CE Primary School, Leigh, in Manchester, announced the new rules on social media at the weekend.
